Award.AwardTitle: Arcs, Valuations, and Multiplier Ideals on Algebraic Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is in the field of algebraic geometry. At the core of algebraic geometry is the quest for classification of algebraic varieties, which are sets of solutions of systems of polynomial equations (or various generalizations of this concept). Classification roughly splits into two parts: birational classification, in which varieties that look alike almost everywhere are organized in the same class, and moduli theory, where continuous deformations of varieties are studied. The minimal model program is the major tool for the birational classification of algebraic varieties, and it has important applications to the theory of moduli. Designed over the model of classification of surfaces, the minimal model program has become one of the major trends in algebraic geometry, earning S. Mori the Fields Medal for work on three dimensional varieties. Recently, there has been groundbreaking progress which brings the subject very close to a complete program in all dimensions. There are however many fundamental questions that still remain unanswered, and some of these constitute the main objectives of this research project. The local study of algebraic varieties and their singularities is a natural component of this study.

The project has two main objectives. The first objective concerns a conjecture of Shokurov from 1988 which predicts that a certain local invariant of singularities, known as the minimal log discrepancy, varies semicontinuously. This property is closely connected to a conjecture on termination of flips which has implications to the minimal model program, and relates to a series of specific questions concerning the geometry of spaces of arcs and their connections to valuation spaces and Berkovich analytic spaces. The second objective deals with multiplier ideals on algebraic varieties. There are various notions of multiplier ideals on singular varieties, and the PI will explore a unifying approach which incorporates all theories and explains their connections. This part of the project contains various applications, from a Reider-type theorem on the global generation of twists of the dualizing sheaf of a normal surface, to the comparisons between certain notions of singularities defined in characteristic zero and in positive characteristics. The project also includes educational activities and other broader impacts. These include the participation in outreach programs, various forms of dissemination including the writing of a book on the birational geometry of algebraic varieties, and the organization of several activities at various levels, ranging from undergraduate summer schools to international conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In regards to intellectual merits, the research carried out under this grant has led to new discoveries and results in the field of algebraic geometry which provide steps towards the understanding of several aspects regarding the structure of the singularities of algebraic varieties.

The most important results obtained during the duration of the grant have been in the context of arc spaces of algebraic varieties. Since the pioneering work of Nash in the late 1960’s and the structural theorems of Greenberg and Kolchin from the same period, spaces of arcs have become a central object of study by algebraic geometers. They provide the underlying space in motivic integration and retain information about resolutions of singularities and certain invariants of singularities that naturally appear in the context of the minimal model program. This has led to important applications in birational geometry. The structure of the space of arcs of an algebraic variety is however quite mysterious and hard to describe.

Several papers written by the PI during this period have provided new insight into the geometry of arc spaces. Perhaps the most significant one is a collaboration with Roi Docampo which has let to a new and elegant formula for the sheaf of differentials of the space of arcs of a variety (and, more generally, of an arbitrary scheme). What the PI and Docampo realized in this paper is that a simple and useful description of the sheaf of differentials can help understand key aspects of the structure of the space itself. Using their formula, they have obtained a number of new results as well as simpler and more direct proofs of various theorems in the literature, shedding new light on some of the fundamental properties of the theory. The PI expects that this approach will have many more applications in the future, and is already exploring some of them with Docampo and Christopher Chiu. Other papers on the topic of arc spaces written during this time include collaborations of the PI with Mircea Mustata, Lawrence Ein, and Shihoko Ishii.

The research of the PI has also touched other topics, from birational rigidity of singular Fano varieties to non-archimedean geometry and motivic integration. In collaboration with his postdoc Yu-Chao Tu, the PI has written a paper on links of isolated singularities. A theorem of Mumford states that, on complex surfaces, any normal isolated singularity whose link is diffeomorphic to a sphere is actually a smooth point, and while this property fails in higher dimensions, McLean asks whether the contact structure that the link inherits from its embedding in the variety may suffice to characterize smooth points among normal isolated singularities; he proves that this is the case in dimension 3. The PI and Tu used techniques from birational geometry to extend McLean’s result to a large class of higher dimensional singularities; they also introduced a more refined invariant of the link using CR geometry, and conjectured that this invariant is strong enough to characterize smoothness in full generality. This conjecture was later solved by the PI under the support of a more recent NSF grant.

From the point of view of broader impacts, the PI has been active with organizing a number of activities (including 7 workshops and conferences), editing three books, supervising graduate and undergraduate students, and mentoring postdocs. In 2015, the PI was one of the organizers of the AMS Summer Research Institute in Algebraic Geometry that took place in Salt Lake City. This is a major event in the field, which has been regularly run every ten years following a meeting organized by Zariski in 1954, the other editions being at Woods Hole in 1964, Arcata in 1974, Bowdoin in 1985, Santa Cruz in 1995, and Seattle in 2005. The PI was also one of the organizers of the Graduate Student Bootcamp that preceded the AMS Summer Research Institute.
